format: A data frame with 38 observations on the following 15 variables.

parameters.water: water supply region, a factor with levels Battersea New River Kew; see Details
parameters.popn: population, in the middle of 1849, a numeric vector
parameters.cholera_deaths: number of deaths registered from cholera in 1849, a numeric vector
parameters.house_val: total house values, a numeric vector
parameters.elevation: elevation, in feet above the high water mark, a numeric vector
parameters.region: a grouping of the London districts, a factor with levels West North Central South Kent
parameters.house_valpp: average annual value of house, per person (pounds), a numeric vector
parameters.persons_house: persons per inhabited house, a numeric vector
parameters.houses: number of houses, a numeric vector
parameters.poor_rate: poor rate precept per pound of house value, a numeric vector
parameters.cholera_drate: deaths from cholera in 1849 per 10,000 inhabitants, a numeric vector
parameters.pop_dens: population density (persons per acre), a numeric vector
parameters.district: name of the district in London, a character vector
parameters.annual_deaths: annual deaths from all causes, 1838-1844, a numeric vector

title: William Farr's Data on Cholera in London, 1849
description:
Description
In 1852, William Farr, published a report of the Registrar-General on mortality
due to cholera in England in the years 1848-1849, during which there was a
large epidemic throughout the country.  Farr initially believed that cholera
arose from bad air ("miasma") associated with low elevation above the
River Thames. John Snow (1855) later showed that the disease was principally
spread by contaminated water.
This data set comes from a paper by Brigham et al. (2003) that analyses some
tables from Farr's report to examine the prevalence of death from cholera
in the districts of London in relation to the available predictors from
Farr's table.
